description.text: This is a simple calibration object designed to test accuracy of your x, y and z axis linear travel, angular alignment and slicing settings, with some small bridges thrown in.

Update: 19/03/2013
Hi Everyone, it's great to see so many people finding this piece useful in their calibration. It was one of the first things I designed after building my printer, so I was still fairly new at this when I put this up. I've updated some of the hints & tips below to reflect what I've learned since then. Cheers, Matt I have since discovered Triffid Hunter's Calibration Guide, http://reprap.org/wiki/Triffid_Hunter%27s_Calibration_Guide This has proved invaluable in helping me finetune my printer. I'd recommend anyone who is trying to improve their print quality run through his guide, especially the Temperature & E-STeps fine tuning sections. I use those two processes with each new batch of filament and it has greatly improved my print quality.

The 1/4 pyramid is made up of 5mm cubes. Use calipers to measure the dimensions of each block and the depth of each level. With multiple prints I tested the effects of different slicing, firmware & printer settings against the printed object. Description:
Object overall x, y, z dimension = 25mm.
Each layer of cubes is 5mm high.
Base layer cutout: 5mm high, 5mm deep, 10mm wide.
2nd layer cutout: 5mm high, 5mm deep, 5mm wide. I used this object to test:
x,y,z travel against a known design:
Once you have the correct E-Steps to match your mechanical setup, I found that the next two issues that affected linear accuracy were: Temperature & Extruder E-Step Fine Tuning. See the linked Calibration guide above. Fine tuning my Extruder E-Step calibration was the difference between an accuracy of +0.4mm to +0.5mm and +/-0.1 to 0.05mm. Angular accuracy:
Once you have aligned your printers axis to be perpendicular, this object is of limited use. I found it easier to print out circular objects to test for angular accuracy, as now I was finding that one axis was sliding at a different rate to the other, resulting in ellipses, or squashed circles. Improvements from here focused on reducing the friction in the axis and improving the belt tension.
  • Reducing axis friction (specifically for Reprap Prusa Mendel):
    First - Ensure that your guide rods are parallel and your carriage doesn't bind up on any point. Your build instructions will have instructions on how to set this for your printer, but on mine there were little grub screws for adjusting the location of the rods. Use a treadlocking compound (like Loctite) or spring washers to ensure they don't come loose under vibration.
    Second - Reconsider your y-axis carriage. The Makergear Reprap Prusa Mendel y-axis carriage has a tendancy to bind up on the y-axis when you are leveling the bed. Rearrange the fastener/spring arrangement to rectify this. From the side, working from the top down, my solution was: Screw head (M4x40 socket head) - M4 Washer - Wooden Build Platform - M4 Washer - Spring - M4 Washer - ~6mm of spacers (I used more washers) - Plywood Y-axis carriage mount - M4 Washer - M4 Locknut. This arrangement removes the tendancy for plywood carriage to warp and bind when your are levelling the bed, provides a degree of give to the build platform should you drive the head into it, and gives sufficient tension to the mount that I haven't had to relevel the bed in 6 months since I switched over.
  • Improve Belt Tension: Add the spring from some old school wooden clothes pegs to your belt. Pic - http://www.iheartrobotics.com/2009/11/timing-belt-tensioner.html - The new Makerbot Replicator has a similar spring to tension their belts.
    • Bridging:
    The cutouts help with checking your small bridging settings, and slicing settings for overhangs: These were added more for interest than anything else. To properly calibrate your bridging/overhang settings, I recommend printing some dedicated bridging calibration pieces such as: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9804 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12925 Slicing settings:
    If you are finding that the top layer or two are being printed as solid cubes and bulging at the sides, see if you can adjust the minimum solid infill area setting on your slicing program. I use Slic3r (Current Ver. 0.9.8), and the setting is: Print Settings -> Infill -> Solid infill threshold area. This was set to 70mm^2 by default. Drop it down to 20mm^2 and the top cube should be printed like any other. Top surface layer fill Vs perimeters & infill.
    See Triffid Hunter's Calibration guide for how to adjust Extruder E-Steps on the fly to calibration top surface infill. Vertical Walls
    Wall building and the effect on print speed Vs the quality of the vertical wall printed.
    See the temperature section of the calibration guide. I found that higher print temperatures cause too much oozing of filament on the corners of the cubes. Fine-tuning the temperature as per the guide will allow you to see the effects of extrusion tempeature changes on corners & extrusion quality. Cooling settings on small layers (such as the top cube layer, as above).
    Here you can adjust your small perimeter settings and minimum speed/layer time/fan speed settings. I am still trying to find a good combination here for my printer. My current settings for this are Small Perimeters - 30mm/s, with a speed reduction if the layer time is below 10s, and a min. print speed of 15mm/s. Base Layer Height:
    If your base layer is too low, then that will affect the first few layers of your print. I replaced the default z-axis stop on my printer with one which gave me much finer control over the setting of the z-axis height and calibrating your base layer heigh properly can be the difference between putting a perfect print off the desk, an aborted print, and spending time reworking the model to trim back the squished out base layers. There are other calibration objects out there that do similar or more things, but I had fun printing multiple pyramids out to check the results of different settings.

remixed_from.author: Jamie-Clay
remixed_from.title: Mavic Pro Getterback mount with optional flasher

title: Mavic Pro Getterback side saddle mount (with optional flasher)

description.text:
When flying out over deep water (obviously not a pool as picture) you can increase your chances for recovery with a Getterback locked to your Mavic Pro.

The Getterback (available from many sporting goods stores and Amazon) is designed to release a float after being submerged for any duration. It will release in 10 minutes and should allow for recovery in water up to 100'.

If you add the optional flasher, you can only increase your chances of finding the float in the water, especially if you're flying at night. The flasher will run on fresh batteries for a couple of days.

These are the flashers I used. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00L1UPKLC/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

NOTE: Shortly after making the original design - where the GetterBack was mounted on the top - I realize there was a 50/50 chance the sinking Mavic might settle on its top preventing the float to deploy. So in this revision places the GetterBack on the side - reducing that risk.

Double Dog Note: I've added a version with two GetterBack saddles - I've not tested the print but in theory it should work as well as the single. Please give me feedback if there are problems with the dual saddle design.

title: Sound dampening bush for use with acoustic washers to make printer quiet.

description.text:
In my article http://tronxy.wikia.com/wiki/Tips_for_the_TronXY_P802MA_and_in_general in the second tip I mentioned you can use sound dampening silicone washers to make your printer quieter. The part above spreads the load of the tiny M3 bolt head to cover the full area of the silicone washer. This makes the sound much less and lets the washer last much longer.

You can also add two washers to the Y axis pulley mount. I added short bushes for this because the screws might be short otherwise.

I estimate the sound reduction is down to 1/4 of what it was before but I have rubber under the frame also. If you just have silicone washers I estimate the sound is at least halved.

I also removed the rear support of the Y axis motor on my TronXY P802MA because I needed sound reduction more than I wanted to avoid banding. Update: here is my design for the rear support with two acoustic washers - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2428376.

I have been able to print at 120mm/s with much less noise. The same noise as 30mm/s without washers.

I made these 6mm high because I only had 20mm long M3 bolts. The right size was 14mm without bushes, but the TronXY P802MA comes with a bunch of extra M3 x 20 bolts.

Update: Also print two of smooth rod spacers to place at the top or bottom of the smooth rods to account for the thickness of the sound dampening washers.

Printer:

TronXY P802MA

No

Doesn't Matter

Print a skirt or brim for clean extrusion. Slow speed helps also.

title: Motor /Generator Stator Casting Mold (7.75" diameter with 12 slots)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an experimental stator casting mold process. The outer diameter is 7.75". The inner diameter is 4.0625". The depth is 2.125". This is for the more advanced tinkerer. It represents an effective alternative to silicone steel or metglas/ceramic type stators for the home inventor/builder. There are many magnet and wiring arrangements that one can experiment with. You design your own motor/generator housing, bearing holders, and wire scheme/circuit. Telsagenx has some basic circuits for running pulse motors/energizers and energy recovery circuits if that is a direction you would like to go with this. Follow this project at : http://www.energyscienceforum.com/showthread.php?t=3848

Disclaimer: Experiment at your own risk. The end product (actual stator) has not been thoroughly tested for heat dissipation, load testing, or reliability. Sourced products that I have used in the completion of my stator have been outside of the manufactures recommendations. This represents what worked for me. You may not have the same results.

There is an optional rotor file for a generator or pulse motor. The magnet size is 2" X 1/2" X 1/8". The shaft size is 3/4". The set screw size is 1/8".

Video instruction: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LzC5SP4e_uA
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aPIIT2ObSvc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3uz2U-aGob4

07/08/2017 at 14:32 est: added sample motor end/ bearing holders
I completed the file for sample motor end/ bearing holders. This is what I will use on mine. It is for 3/4" X 1 5/8" X 7/16" bearings. The inner bolts are 6-32 X 3/4" and the outer holes will be for 1/8" threaded rod to connect both sides. There will be an inch of room on both sides of the stator for wire to stick out. Pictures are included here. You will need to print or have printed (2) bearing holders and (8) legs (4) for each side.

08/11/2017: added new bearing legs that hold the stator in the middle. (takes 1/4" X 5" bolts)
added a 9-piece rotor for people with small printer beds. (takes M4-.70 X 60 bolts..4 of them)

               added stator end caps to hold the wire back..Just glue them on with Gorilla glue

author: Reflector36

description.text:
Where can you go with the Drake Dragonfly? You’re on Terra. Take a look at the horizon and pick out any point. A looming mountain, a faraway alien ocean teaming with life, a distant megapolis. You’ll be there in no time. Now you’re on Port Olisar. Crane your neck up and pick anything in the heavens. A blazing star, a desolate moon, a looming asteroid. The Dragonfly, Drake’s first ultralight ship, will take you there… and beyond!

Drake Interplanetary is fond of claiming that they build starships for the way you live; with the Dragonfly, they’ve gone an extra step and built a new way of life around the ship itself. Highly compact for easy storage anywhere and capable of traversing both space and ground, the 2947 Dragonfly changes the way we think about ships.

I made this battery cover for my frienda and it's very useful to cover any format battery.

It can be assembled with specific screws or with sticks.

If you wish, you can support me with a little donation:

https://www.patreon.com/lorenzociffo

Thank you so much for the continuos support! :)

title: Mavic Pro Gimbal Guard / Glare Shield

description.text:
Changes from other designs

  • Increased the FOV and added a cowl. Tested the shield to make sure it rarely enters frame.
  • Made a better, tighter fit at the back clip (at least on my Mavic),
  • Strengthened and thickened the base of the print so it can be printed without a raft.

Notes: I don't like having to need a raft to print so I added a little box at the apex of the arch so you can add supports. As a sun shade/glare shield it seems to work about as good as you might expect. I do feel better about the exposed gimbal when I have this on. I've shot a bunch of footage with this shield and the intrusion into the shot is far less than others I've tried.

title: Universal Phone Tripod Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
get a sneak peak on my latest works in progress on patreon



This is a universal clamp to use a phone with a standard tripod camera mount.I couldn't seem to find one of these so I just made one for myself. I also used the opportunity to try out a new thread mechanism I was toying with.

This design features angled clamping surfaces that don't interfere with the volume buttons (on my phone). The base also incorporates a spring-loaded jaw for smoother tightening on the phone, adding wax from a candle / soap bar makes tightening smoother as well.

See it working:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxVFlWWsE6Q

Additional parts needed:
-1/4-20 size nut for the tripod attachment
-wax to put on threads

comments.text: Here's the solution for anyone else in my scenario...if your slicer supports changing extrusion width...lower it to .35 and scale model up to 105%. If changing extrusion width doesn't work well with your slicer....printing at 115% will make all the missing areas of the model slice and print correctly.

title: Openbuilds Mini V Gantry Shim for K40 Laser Cutter - 21.2mm

description.text:
This shim is used as part of my Openbuilds-based rail system re-design for the K40 "Cheap Chinese" Blue and White 40W Laser Cutter (commonly bought off eBay). It's a remix of the Openbuilds Mini V Gantry itself, to ensure a uniform fit.

The shim is necessary to ensure the height of the various mirror stages remains accurate and consistent.

You can see the application of this shim in context by reviewing the build itself on Sketchup Warehouse here: https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model/074a52c9-1c45-46a3-9ad7-587e9b4ac8e5/Openbuilds-CO2-Laser-Rail-System-for-K40

Generally, this shim, in conjunction with the 11.2mm shim could be useful for anyone who needs to stack two Openbuilds Linear Actuator bundles on top of one another, and have the resulting height be a multiple of 20mm (standard v rail dimension).

comments.text: Heads up: The current version of this design does not include wide enough holes for Openbuilds Low Profile M5 screw heads in the center 5 holes. I will be uploading a revision soon that widens them out to 9.2mm which is .1mm larger than the intended screw head.

title: Sine Cosine Graph Template
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a template for students to be able to draw nicely shaped sine and cosine curves while they are learning how the equations relate to the graphs. I've designed a few active learning activities to go with the templates. A few are uploaded, and I'll be uploading a couple more files in the near future. I created this as part of an NSF grant to infuse more active learning and 3d-printed manipulatives into trigonometry classes.

Printer:

Qidi Tech I

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I had a heated bed, so a raft was not required. You may or may not need to scrape some strings out with an X-acto knife, depending on how well your printer does. This was designed so that most pens/pencils should be able to work in tracing out the curve.

This was designed in OpenSCAD. I wanted to be able to draw 2 full cycles of either sin(x) or cos(x), so that is the thought behind where the template starts and stops. It is not meant to have a specific scale, but rather for students to write in the scale afterward based on the equation they are trying to graph.
CCSS

I got tired of seeing sawtooth curves or curves that had severe symmetry problems when students were trying to graph sine and cosine functions.  This template is meant to help students create decent sine and cosine curves as they are learning how the equations and graphs are related.  This was created as part of an NSF grant to help infuse 3d-printing and active learning into trigonometry classes.

Student Activities All Student activities and Instructor Notes/Answer Key are included in the uploaded files. The first lesson investigates basic sine and cosine curves with amplitude, period, and vertical shift changes. The second lesson incorporates these as well as horizontal shifts. Lessons are designed for a 50 min period, although these may take longer, depending on the level of students in the class.

Print the Lessons and provide 1 copy per student. There is an answer key included in the instructor notes. I didn't intend for these to be graded activities except perhaps using an effort score. These are more for students to discuss, work in groups, and learn as they go.
You will need 1 template per student as well, though you might be able to get by with 1 for every 2 students in a pinch.
There is also a desmos link in the first lesson that you may find useful as a demonstration before students start, and you will need a computer with internet connected to a projector to use that link.

author: angelinama

description.text:
Fabricación del Robot Cargo Artesanal.

Se utilizará cartón de 2mm de espesor y se unirán las partes con encastres hechos a medida. Los componentes del mismo se ira podrán pegar al cartón posteriormente.

Se detalla a continuación la elaboración de la fabricación de las pizas:

Primero se realizó el diseño de las piezas en un croquis a mano alzada para tener una idea global del mismo, luego lo diseñe digital en Tinkercad, lo exporté en SVG y lo abrí con inkscape para imprimírlo en dos hojas A4 y así tener el diseño de las piezas en papel.
Superpuse los diseños de papel sobre el cartón de 2 milimetros de espesor y con una cortaplumas realicé todos los cortes sobre el cartón. Una vez obtenida todas las partes las uní mediante los encastres realizados.

Vuelvo a reiterar que mi diseño carece de profesionalismo, pero me es complejo conseguir materiales en donde estoy, de mi parte hubiera sido mas sencillo enviar el diseño y que me lo impriman y no estar 3 horas cortando el cartón de las partes.

Con este dispositivo tu puedes montar cualquier celular o tablet en cualquier microscopio. Usando dos modelos distintos para diferentes tamaños de oculares.
Todas las distancias son regulables usando los carriles, para ajustar la posicion debera ajustar los tornillos y tuercas de metrica 3.
Tanto para el armado del dispositivo como para el acople al microscopio tu puedes ver el siguiente video

With this device you can mount any cell or tablet in any microscope. Using two different models for different sizes of eyepieces.
All distances are adjustable using the rails, to adjust the position must adjust the screws and nuts (metric 3).
Both for the assembly of the device and for the attachment to the microscope you can see the following video

comments.text: Hola! Cómo estás? Baje los planos e hice imprimir las piezas; el tema es que no termino de darme idea cómo armarlo, tenes algun planito del despiece? Muchas gracias!
comments.author: maumazzei

comments.text: Hola, como estas? Te cuento mas o menos como seria, te podes guiar con la segunda foto, que tiene las partes y su interaccion, ahi solo faltan los tornillos. El archivo tiene dos soportes centrales (uno corto y otro largo, por si usas celular o tablet) y dos juegos de sujeta oculares por si tu microscopio tiene oculares grandes o comunes. Elegi un soporte central y un juego de sujeta oculares y armalo con los tornillos, usando los largos para sujetar el soporte central a los dos extremos que sirven para prensar el telefono o tablet. Una vez que lo armaste, mi recomendacion es que no lo termines de apretar, primero, retira un ocular del micro y sujetalo al sujeta oculares, chequeando que quede firme. A partir de este punto podes, luego de sujetar el ceular o tablet, centrar la camara del celular con el ocular que fijaste y una vez que te parece que quedo bien ahi ajustas los tornillos que faltan, volves a poner el ocular en su lugar junto con todo el dispositivo y el celu o tablet y listo, puede ser que ahi te des cuenta que no quedo del todo centrado pero eso lo podes corregir con todo armado, suele ser muy pequeña la correccion a realizar. Espero te haya servido. Un abrazo, Carlos.

description.text: The CollossOS begleri are a bigger, heavier, tougher version of Aroundsquare's Titan OS. I was able to get a set of 2 beads up to 40g with 3 hex nuts. I've also widened the holes in the bead to allow for stringing it up in 550 opposed to 275 paracord.

description.text:
External undoable Spool Holder for Flashforge Dreamer

Exchange the left Door with this Holder. Add a Teflon Tube (4mm outer diameter) to help the Filament getting into the build room. You can even use it without the tube, but it reduces the friction significantly. (Hint: you can easily get such a tube at amazon)

The Filament will be guided through the door directly, so you don't need to drill any holes into your dreamer, no Spacers for the top Lid are necessary.

To insert the door, slide it up to the top and push the bottom in. Release it to let it fall down. The top notch is slightly deeper to hold it in place.

title: Hubsan X4 v2 Prop guard

description.text:
Just putting this up quickly but may need some updating. Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:223412 I wanted to try creating my own in OpenSCAD. I've tried to make it parametric but it needs some comments, so I'll update it.
You can change the motor mounting details and distance to the rim etc. I wanted to use it to quickly be able to slim down or beef up as needed after some flight testing to see how light it could get and still protect the quad.
This is a work in progress :)
Update: Added quick photo
Update: A much needed refactor to simplify the code and remove duplication and redundant sections. This also has slightly smaller tabs as I was reducing weight. Update: Added just a single corner stl. I've not tried it, but you could print 4 corners then super glue them together. It has rotational symmetry so all the corners are the same. You could use a bit of tape for strength.

MKSA, I don't understand you from de beginning. I just upload a coupling that works really fine for me, Is correctly align and the dimension of the holes are exactly what they have to be. For me is a fact that works, so...why do you think is bad or worse than the original? tell me your appreciation and let me discuss it.
On the other hand, I never criticized your designs, if I see something that for me is lame, too complex, fragile, don't work properly or at all my action is simple...I don't care, don't print it or even better I just continue to look for something better in my opinion.

Bye

description.text:
I bought a new Dial indicator and found none of the holders on here fit it snugly as mine has a 55mm diameter back, so i designed a new one. This will hold this dial indicator (found here: https://goo.gl/E1p39i) snugly as long as you remove the back-plate or replace it with a 3D printed back-plate (Mine is found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2424111)

This helped me level my Monorprice Maker Select V2.1 in under a minute.

Versions:
v2 I have added 2 new versions for dials with 57mm backs.
If you have a digital dial gauge you will most likely need the 57mm - digital file. If you dont have a digital dial indicator i can quarantee it works with the following dial indicator. https://goo.gl/UDs6BL

comments.text: Nice job. I have the Maker 3IP, and made a dial indicator for mine as well. At first, I thought I was a freakin' genious because it was sooo much easier to level the bed, but I started to think that the pressure from the pin might be affecting the reading. Also, the way mine was setup, the pin was pretty far from where the nozzle is, further throwing off the accuracy (the pin was pretty far forward, so I wasn't getting close enough to the back springs for leveling). I since realized that the X axis traverse rods weren't level to the frame in the first place (by 50mm  or more side to side!) so that might've been the real issue.
comments.author: alsoknownasjazz

comments.text: I relevel my x axis once a month or so, but it’s ususally not off by much if anything at all. This method has been working for me perfectly since I designed this mod. As long as I have a good starting point, then it comes out glass flat.

description.text:
This is a custom point tracker I made for a friend. They wanted one small device they could carry around that could be used both as a score tracker, and as a suit/score tracker for other games like Uker or Phase10. I used the spring mechanism from the remixed item (and the base idea), making a small enclosure and two wheels. One has the numbers 0-9, the other 0-9 and the four suits.

I've included the OpenSCAD files, so if you want to localize it, or change the number of bumps per wheel, you can easily do so. The two wheels call a function to generate, and are only 2 or 3 lines each in code. Note that the SCAD file has four of the parts, but not the spring, as I did not model that, needing no changes to it.

101Hero

title: Heavy Tripod Pad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is one of tripod pads/foots I plan to create for telescope tripod mounts legs to provide either isolation of floor from tripod studs. Provide reliable stand of tripod on sand or any other ground surface.
The pads should survive under EQ6 telescope mount whose overall weight is 34 kg without telescope (7.3kg tripod + 10.2 kg of counterweight + 16.5 kg for mount head), and may reach 52 kg maximum with full telescope load. This is why the pads are necessary when playing with the mount and telescope on the floor or in field with not reliable ground surface.

Print 1 pad for each tripod leg.

UPD1:

  • 07/11/2017 - I added ABS version with support to help print it with ABS plastic in open printer. External wall around the printed model helps prevent quick cooldown of external wall in open (non-box) printers, that cause warping of the object, and leads to print fail. The ABS model still requires raft to prevent warping - this gives most of anti-warp measures. Finally I printed all 3 pads having last 2 pads printed with UPD1 model and they have less warping than the first pad (2mm vs 3.5mm side rise over table). While they are not perfect, but anyway they do what they intended for.

Printer:

JGAURORA Z - 605S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Layer 0.2 mm Nozzle 0.4 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I use ABS plastic for high hit resistance and some flexibility. Walls are chosen 4.8mm. With 15% I save only ~25% of plastic. Bright color will help to find the pads after observations.
The STL with embedded support is attached as well for 0.4 nozzle to print without slicer support. Just clean the printed pads from the minimal support after print.
I used OpenSCAD for model creation and Blender for model cleanup to reduce files size.

description.text:
This weapon is ready to be printed in 3d and adapted to the new control of the PlayStation PSR VR AIM CONTROLLER;
I was watching the movie, THE CALL UP and then I thought of making a weapon-shaped adapter to fit the PS VR AIM CONTROLLER in this control; PlayStation has a very good control in my opinion because it is light, has a very discrete format and fulfills well the function of gun cable, so you will be able to adapt many types of 3D weapon model printed on the ps vr aim controller ;
I believe that feeling the weight, the palpable texture of the weapon helps to deceive the brain so that we have a deeper immersion in virtual reality.

title: moai Easter Island head plant spike

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ksMaVHZeBb2

I wanted to hide unsightly water bottles in my house plants, so I was inspired by this model of the Easter Island Head. I opened up the interior to a 2 1/2 inch (64mm) diameter so that a small water bottle could be used as a water "tank" and added a 5" inch (127mm) long hollow spike for plenty of soil depth. Since I have literally just finished the design, I'll add an update when the print is done and it is established in it's new home.

comments.text: I'll be working on a conversion so that the stake can be threaded into the "head". This should make it more print friendly.

title: Openbuilds Mini V Gantry Shim for K40 Laser Cutter - 11.2mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This shim is used as part of my Openbuilds-based rail system re-design for the K40 "Cheap Chinese" Blue and White 40W Laser Cutter (commonly bought off eBay). It's a remix of the Openbuilds Mini V Gantry itself, to ensure a uniform fit.

The shim is necessary to ensure the height of the various mirror stages remains accurate and consistent.

You can see the application of this shim in context by reviewing the build itself on Sketchup Warehouse here: https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model/074a52c9-1c45-46a3-9ad7-587e9b4ac8e5/Openbuilds-CO2-Laser-Rail-System-for-K40

Generally, this shim, used in conjunction with the 21.2mm shim, could be useful for anyone who needs to stack two Openbuilds Linear Actuator bundles on top of one another, and have the resulting height be a multiple of 20mm (standard v rail dimension).

comments.text: Heads up: The current version of this design does not include wide enough holes for Openbuilds Low Profile M5 screw heads in the center 5 holes. I will be uploading a revision soon that widens them out to 9.2mm which is .1mm larger than the intended screw head.

title: Idler Pulley for 624 Bearing and GT2 belt

description.text:
This is an idler pulley to suit a 624 bearing (4x13x5mm). The pulley outer diameter is 18mm, internal diameter 13mm and overall height is 8.4mm. The pulley outer channel is 6.4mm high by 1.5mm deep.

Assemble with a 624 bearing, M4 machine screw and an M4 washer to give some clearance for the bearing to rotate.

I made this pulley to stop the belt from slipping off the bearings in this drawing robot:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1517211

There's also a spacer included with 8mm OD x 4mm ID x 3.5mm height, which was needed with the drawing robot, to add a bit of clearance to fit the new pulleys.

comments.text: I've printed this file but my bearing dont fit in it
comments.author: prathameshjakka

comments.text:
Hi, the internal diameter is exactly 13mm, and it was designed without any clearance so that it would be a very tight "interference fit" on a 13mm bearing. This assumes your printer is reasonably well calibrated and is printing accurate dimensions. Assuming it has printed at the right size, and your bearing is 13mm outer diameter, you could try placing the bearing on a flat surface, and put the pulley on top of it with the larger internal diameter facing down. Make sure the pulley is level and not tilted. Put something flat (like a coaster) on top of the pulley, and give it a tap with something heavy to push the pulley onto the bearing. Alternatively, you could try warming things up a bit.
You could also try slightly increasing the size by scaling it in your slicer.
Hope this helps.
comments.author: prathameshjakka

title: Anet A6 Auto Bed Level Probe and Fan Mount Upgrade

description.text:
Mount for standard 12mm inductive probe, enabling you to have Auto Bed Level for Anet A6.

Benefits:

  • Direct replacement for kit acrylic mount plate.
  • No need to modify x-carriage end stop.
  • Close to extruder tip for better probing and avoid reducing print area.
  • Stable and stiff probe mount.

Use standard 12mm inductive proximity probe like the LJ12A3-4-Z/BX - Search eBay LJ12A3-4-Z/BX

Most probes rated for 6 - 36V supply can run on 5V, but be aware that this voltage is too low and can result in unreliably distance measuring.

I recommend that the probe is supplied with 12V from the power supply. As the suggested probe is NPN (open collector) type output, it will not output any voltage but connect to 0V (GND) when activated.
It is therefore safe to connect directly to Z-min input on the Arduino, without any need for additional electronics. The input pin on the Arduino must be set to have internal pull-up resistor activated to read the signal from the probe correctly.
For additional information, please consult the many guides found on the web.

To assemble you will need an additional M3 12mm bolt and M3 nut to hold the probe in position. Reuse other bolts and screw from the kit.

Initial probe height is approximately 1mm above extruder tip.

You need to adjust the firmware to enable auto bed leveling and specify probe offset from extruder tip (X offset = -28mm, Y offset = 22mm) and (X offset = -28mm, Y offset = 19mm) for centered.

Update 2017.12.10: Added model that centers fan to nozzle (filename with center) and more space for fan notch.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

No

No

0.20mm

25%, rectilinear

Notes:

Part shown is printed in PETG, but use the filament you like.

Then simply added the spiral. Feel free to do with as you please, preferably don't sell it without letting me know...

description.text:
I designed this test bench for easy setup, wiring, testing, and configuring of flight controllers, video transmitters, receivers, etc. Has 4 mounting hole patterns for patterns of 30.5mm, 20mm, and 16mm hole spacings. Perfect for any and all boards on the market. plus 2 tie down spots allow for a receiver or even vtx to be strapped down. Enjoy!

Plate printed in ABS and the feet in TPU. The feet i inserted a m3 nylon standoff and just used a m3 screw from top to bottom :) allows for components to be powered from the back without risking touching components. (huge for me since i use a desktop psu)

TIP - I do recommend tapping the holes with m3 tap for the 30.5mm and 20mm patterns and m2 for the 16mm patterns :)

I was looking to do 2D drawing with my MP Mini Select V1. I couldn't find a single attachment for a pen to do this so I decided to make one myself. You will need to print out both files. The two parts should sandwich a pen by having small binder clips on each side. It is held on right where the fan assembly would have been with the clips for holding the fan. I wired the fan assembly to the bowden tube. I tried it myself and it does work. The hardest thing is using the right software to make the g code. If anybody has some pretty easy ways, I am all ears. I hope you enjoy.

https://youtu.be/yK_YGwMRR40
comments.author: ocieward

comments.author: ocieward

comments.author: Calebmakerboy

comments.text:
you could get quite far generating .svg with Inkscape, extruding them one layer high (0.1 mm) in OpenSCAD, then slicing as usual with Cura, leaving the temperature set to 0.
Or manually editing the gcode files to remove commands to the heaters, since GCode files are just text files after all.
comments.author: DavidPhillipOster

comments.text: Thank you! I will give that a try.
comments.author: DavidPhillipOster

comments.text: Cura generates gcode with a home, then a lift. At that point you can insert a pause in the file (a pause for 30 seconds?) so you can set the pen to the paper. Cura then moves to the start and changes Z back down to start. You'd remove that descend command (Z0?), so the nozzle won't scrape your drawing. That's the new base line. Cura will emit retraction commands when it wants to move without laying down plastic. You'll edit those to move to a higher Z coordinate, and the following extruder command is your cue to move back to your drawing Z-level.
comments.author: Calebmakerboy

comments.text: Thank you this has been so helpful!

title: RC Mini Track Loader (Remixed for SG90 servos)

description.text:
This is a remix of the cute RC Mini track loader from Zedpi.

The Tower Pro SG90 servos are a bit bigger than the specified servo and thus the frame has to be extended about 2mm each side to accomodate the SG90 servos. I am still building this thing and the parts may not well fit together at this moment. Some ergonomic features have been removed at the moment.

I am using Fusion 360 and I am quite a beginner at it, so if anyone with better CAD skills would like to help, just let me know and I can share the fusion files that I have.

Note about the servo arms/horns:

The remix uses the standard servo horns that comes with the Tower Pro SG90 servo. The cross servo arm needs to be cut to fit the cross on the wheels.

Update: 2017 July 9

1) Changed Frame A and Frame B to cater to cable management
2) I don't have the Lego Tracks, but I have some lego Tires, so I have created adapters for them.

comments.text:
IF you are using a programer, you do not use that to load skynet you only use that to load the boot loader. To load Skynet you only need the USB cable attached to the control card and your computer with the Arduino IDE program. You use ANET V1.0 for the board type (NOTE the V1.0 has nothing to do with the version of the board). IF you do not have that listed under Tools / board then you are not using the Arduino IDE that came with the skynet software. You have to select the port you have there maybe two or more ports listed under tools / port keep trying them until one works. IF you are not sure about it read the Arduino website about loading sketches it is the same as loading a normal Arduino... NOTE I could not get skynet to load I finally got a copy of the normal Martin software and used the config files from skynet worked perfect.
IF you are trying to load the bootloader then you select the board ANETV1.0 and the correct programer under tools/programer dont worry about the port... then select burn bootloader. There is no software you have to configure for a bootloader.

Most slicers make holes smaller than the actual design for various reasons. This is a chart you can print so you can test fit items before designing the proper holes for it. I made it only 2.5mm thick as there is no need to go thicker like some other test prints I found. Also I don't skip sizes like some others (I.E. 10, 12, 14).  
This is only round but I may do a square one as well latter.  
The holes are in 1mm increments from 1mm to 25mm.

Print with settings you use most often as this will show you normal sizes for your prints.  
Mark with pen the holes on the print (like image included) note that the first hole (1mm) will likely be filled in and not visible but still mark it. Also look to make sure as the 2mm hole may not print open on some printers. Just remember the first row is from 1mm to 10mm so you can work backwards if needed to get the right markings.

title: Galaxy Nexus Pan and Tilt Platform

description.text:
I liked the design of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:100241, but I wanted to use the Galaxy Nexus as a camera. I designed this platform to use with it. Servos used:
TowerPro MG90S (base)
Futaba S3004 Update #1: Fixed geometry on the lift_arm; it created an odd diagonal.

1) Install the MG90S servo in the base - you can thread the leads through the gaps.
2) Attach the middle_tier to the base servo with a lateral horn.
3) Install the servo in the middle_tier; I used a round horn.
4) Attach the lift arm. It's a close fit, but you can spread the arms of the lift_arm to fit it over the pin and over the servo. Notes: I drilled holes once I matched up the middle tier servo.
The base doesn't have holes, but does need to be mounted for stability when holding a real Galaxy Nexus. Most pieces should just work with self threading screws.

comments.text: It looks great and I want it, but I was surprised at how expensive it is to get all the parts printed for this plus the cellphone holder. Well over $100 on Shapeways. You can buy all this manufactured in hard plastic and metal for that price.

title: Periodic Table of the Elements
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Periodic Table of the Elements has been designed as flash tiles to overlay on the official 2016 IUPAC version (available from https://iupac.org/what-we-do/periodic-table-of-elements/). Another accurate version is available at Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_education#/media/File:Periodic_table_large.svg). This "thing" serves as a studying aid for all students of science in general and of chemistry in particular.

The complete list of elements from 1 Hydrogen to 118 Oganesson are now named for the very first time. For our own copy, we laser engraved a stretched version of the IUPAC Periodic Table of the Elements on a bamboo cutting board using an Epilog Helix Laser Cutter. We then 3D printed each type of elements in a different colour with filaments from a different leading manufacturer as follows:

Alkali Metals - Red - MakerBot True Red PLA
Alkaline Metals - Orange - ESUN Orange PLA
Other Metals - Light Green - Polymaker LulzBot Green PLA
Transition Metals - Yellow - BotFeeder Macaron Yellow PLA
Lanthanoids - Light Purple - ColorFabb Lila PLA/PHA
Actinoids - Hot Pink - Materio3D Fuchsia Pink PLA
Metalloids - Light Blue - FormFutura Light Blue PLA
Nonmetals - Blue - Printrbot Translucent Blue PLA
Halogens - Brown - Proto-Pasta Aromatic Rose HTPLA
Noble Gases - Dark Purple - BEEVERYCREATIVE BEESUPPLIES Violet PLA

We used both MakerBot and LulzBot 3D printers for this project.

Enjoy learning all about what our Universe is made out of!

This is a 45 Degree Miter Sled for my Rigid 4512 table saw. I was having some trouble getting the stock miter guage 45 degree stop set correctly when I saw this on Rockler. http://www.rockler.com/45-degree-miter-sled I was about to go buy this when I thought. Cactus key holder

It is a design made in SolidWorks. The material to be used is sheet metal or plastic.

This is Quadbot 17, a work-in-progress quadruped robot born out of a learning exercise in Autodesk Fusion 360.

This quadruped robot will use AX-12A Dynamixel servos (might be upgraded to the more powerful AX-18A). The legs currently have 20 DoF and there are an additional 2 DoF for the body. Servos and brackets are from the Robotis range, with some replaced by their metal counterparts available from Trossen Robotics. They will be painted to match the colour theme. The rest of the robot is designed with 3D printed parts in mind. The main framework of printed parts forming the body will be sandwiched between 1.5 mm thick custom plates.

The novel aspects of this quadruped are its articulated legs, which have higher DOF than usually found on small quadrupeds, and its articulated "spine", which will help it in navigating uneven terrain.

A number of options are considered for the "head", or main sensor pack: an XBOX Kinect v2 time-of-flight sensor, a Scanse Sweep LiDAR and an Intel RealSense depth-sensing camera.

Currently, a hardware test rig of one leg has been built, and the kinematics have been calculated and tested.

Update 18-12-2017

A temporary chassis has been built using MakerBeam aluminium profiles, so the next stage is to start building the CAD modelled chassis, out of aluminium sheets and 3D parts, then focusing on getting more effective walking gaits.
A walking gait has also been implemented: A Python test program reads the up/down and forward/back position of each leg for a number of frames that make up a walking gait, the IK is solved, and the resulting joint values are streamed via serial over to an Arbotix-M, which simply updates the servo goal positions.

Update 05-02-2018

The prototype custom chassis is complete!
All parts of the custom chassis have been printed in PLA plastic on a FlashForge Creator Pro. The structure is strengthened by pairs of aluminium plates. All plastic parts have been sanded and spray-painted.
I threaded the holes on all the 3D parts, which were either 3 mm wide where the aluminium plates attach, or 2 mm at the leg and spine bracket attachment points. Using a tap for the 3 mm holes worked pretty well, but the 2 mm holes were more prone to being stripped or too loose, so manually threading the holes with the bolts worked better.

Further information

For news and updates on progress of this robot, visit Cognitive Dissonance.

title: Tevo Tarantula Bed Level Knob WIDE

description.text:
Created this using TinkerCad, inspiration from the CR-10 bed level knob created by Valsrath. I was immediately spoiled by how easy it was to bed level once I had his knobs installed on my machine. Wanted the same experience for my Tevo, hadn't yet seen anything like this, so I made my own. It's a tight fit, intentionally, highly recommend removing the bed level nuts and then gently hammer them in place.

Designed this to use minimal amount of filament, but does appear to be plenty strong. I printed this on my CR-10.

author: YellowScope

description.text:
This is a holder for a replaceable rain gauge tube, or udometer. See the photos for the glass replacement tube info. I buy mine at Menards up here in northern USA for about $5.

The holder is a simple plate that allows one to attach it to a railing like on a deck. The first one I made clips to my deck railing, but since most railings are different I created this simple flat one that can be screwed down to any flat surface. The holes are 3mm which works great for #4 sized stainless steel screws.

The calibration ring helps the gauge read correctly. The glass tube is flanged outwards at the top which allows extra water to roll into the tube. This results in readings that can be 30% larger than the actual rain fall. The calibration ring should fit snugly so that water can't run into the gauge between the glass and the ring. I simply silicone it in place.

Be sure to mount the gauge in a place that has an open view of the sky and is not shadowed by buildings or trees.

Here is my Draciel design i remade based on the hasbro Beyblade Draciel F and Draciel S. This attack ring is intended to fit on the original first generation beyblade. Like most of my beyblade designs i have made parts of the attack ring larger or thicker for more durability. I will upload the STL file soon for download Printed on my 5th Gen Replicator
2 shells, 5% infill, 0.20mm
I will do another high print of it soon with more infill and i might try 0.05mm
Let me know if you have any questions

Upload New STL file Draciel.thing
Print the file
Clean and Let it rip!
:)
( NOTE: i have had some issues opening the old file in Makerbot Desktop. If you find that only one small component of the attach ring only shows up, then try open it in another program to display it correctly. I had to use Autodesk3D print utility to open the file and then save it again and upload the save in Makerware.
But i have updated the file and it should work with Desktop) I made this design using the 123D design app on my mac air pro. I used my beyblade template i have uploaded and modelled my own draciel head for my bebyblades unique look. Once you sketch the first draciel head (or whatever other bit beast you prefer) you can extrude each component to preference. Once you have finished the design you can group all pieces and copy and paste to use it as many times as you like and space it around the radius. I had a bit of problems trying to use the circle pattern feature on this design to replicate the draciel head so instead i copied and paste each head to replicate. This took approximately 2-3 hours and this was the first time i used the project feature to put more detail in places i didn't think was possible. I also used colours for the first time and stuck with only two colours for dual nozzle purposes. Enjoy guys and message me if you have any problems or questions :)

description.text:
This was inspired by intofocus's filament clip (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:282242) which I wasn't able to make work for one n00b reason or another; the original's 1.75 mm diameter wouldn't fit my 1.75 mm filament, the little hook in the open end was too delicate to catch the filament, etc.

In the process of making a new hole I realized it really wouldn't be that big a deal to just make a figure 8 and run the clip around the spool once, rather than use a clip that might wear down anyway. So here's my first upload!

When I remember the successful settings I used in Simplify3D to print this, I'll come back with the details. Infill was 50% - it's small enough that internal gaps would be meaningful.

A brim of 4 rings was enough - I didn't use a raft.

Hope it helps, and please let me know if it worked for you. This is all very new and exciting for me, and one day I'll pump out something useful!

description.text:
DISCLAIMER:

I DID NOT CREATE THIS MODEL. THE TALENTED ARTISTS AT OMEGA FORCE DID. I TAKE ABSOLUTELY NO CREDIT FOR THIS WORK. PROPERTY OF KOEI TECMO. USED WITHOUT PERMISSION.

-ripped from one piece: pirate warriors 3 in-game
-edited in blender
-removed necklace, earings, bikini strap, florets, staff, legs, shoes, bangels
-kept eyebrows, hair, eyelashes (somehow i ended up w/ 2 instead of 3 points)
-remodeled 2 armpits and 1 elbow to remove manifold edges

this one was a bit of a disappointment. everything was going so smoothly until i got to the eyes. unfortunately, because her eyes are closed, the eyelids overhang and create a manifold edge while the lashes' vertices don't even line up w/ the rest of the face. i wasted a lot of time on that and ultimately just imported the original lashes and modified them as little as possible, letting netfabb do the rest. also, the triangles in the eye sockets are difficult to add detail to using subsurf--so that looks a bit weird.

i haven't printed this yet, and probably won't for a while until i use up my old bright green filament. so don't print this... i have absolutely no idea how it'll turn out.

this model was subsurface modified at 2x but i can send you a 3x if you really want to print this at a larger size. let me know if you have any questions, issues or recommendations. i'll update this thing once i print it.

Known Issues:
-its a long print, not sure the leg stumps will adhere long enough to your print bed. maybe try rafts
-thin walls are an issue in the hair again... won't notice some strands unless you print big.
-issue where her shirt covers her butt crack (also a thin wall issue) might cause problems.
-maybe the trim around her shorts and bottom of shirt might need supports... not sure.

oh... one last thing. i don't know if i mentioned already that i'm working off the base mesh (sub-mesh) and not the transform (not sure if that's what its called) mesh.

one last thing. i probably should have removed the eyelashes looking at the model now. maybe the eyebrows too.

author: YellowScope

description.text:
This Fidget Spinner is also a variant design of the classic Zoetrope.
A video of a few animations is available at https://youtu.be/fCx5waxvbcg

Construction
The bearing is the 608ZZ skateboard bearing that is typical for spinners. It is tapped into place and the bearing caps are also.
The weights can be your choice. The intent was to use (12) 1/4 dia x 1/4 inch length steel rod segments, but I found Neodymium magnets of the same size which are 2-1/2 times as heavy so only 6 of those are needed. They can be de-magnetized by heating. You can also use buckshot, 1/4 inch dia slingshot balls, lead split-shot weights etc and just epoxy them in place.

Preparation
The final printed animation image strip should have an overall aspect ratio of 9:1 with a height of 0.50 inches and a width of 4.50 inches. The image strip should be comprised of 12 images.
The individual animation frames need to be compressed horizontally by 50% (see below). Most existing 12 frame animation strips that you find will have equal horizontal and vertical scaling and they will create Zoetrope images that are twice as wide as needed.

An easy method of resizing animation strips for printing is to load them into a Microsoft Word document, click on the image and select size. Then change the width to 4.50 inches. The height will resize accordingly and hopefully be approximately 0.50 inches or a little less. The document should print with the animation strips at the proper size.
The PDF file included will print correctly if printed to actual size (100%) on your printer.

Function
The classic Zoetrope is comprised of a cylinder with equally angular spaced slits, with a corresponding equal number of images on the inner surface opposit the slits on the inside of the cylinder. The slits move in the opposite direction of the images.
This Zoetrope functions differently to accomodate the Fidget Spinner bearing. The slits are still on the outer cylinder equally angular spaced, but the images are on the center hub which is a cylinder one-half the diameter of the slit cylinder. This introduces a unique problem. Since the outer cylinder is moving at twice the velocity of the inner cylinder and in the same direction the animated image appears twice as wide while the height remains unaffected. To correct this the animation strip needs to be compressed in width by 50%. (This affect also appears to make the visible number of animated images on the hub reduce by half).

The Tool
The tool is included to make the assembly of the animation strips simpler. You can size and tape the animation and then remove it from the drum by pinching the sides together.

The Shade
The shade can be used to reduce the front surface reflections on the Zoetrope face in bright light.

Miscellaneous
Since the Zoetrope is so small and the animation is viewed at a distance through a tiny slit very little light makes it to the eye. An external light source like a flashlite will probably be needed to illuminate the images.
Laminating the paper images you create with transparent tape will increase their life.

I haven't been able to find any information about a Zoetrope of this design on the internet. This is possibly due to the effects listed above and if this Zoetrope wasn't also a Fidget Spinner I'm sure I would have done it differently too.

description.text: Simple sand shovel I designed for my daughter. Prints great with no support and has no overhangs.

I printed mine up on my Ultimaker2 using 2 shells (0.8mm) and 0.1mm layer thickness (why not?) in PLA, with 15% infill. It took forever (about 13 hours) but it looks great. 3 shells would make it stronger and possibly less porous but it seems fairly sturdy as I printed it. It hasn't been punished by my 2-year-old yet but it has fairly chunky wall thickness and everything is smoothed so there aren't any bad stress points (especially on the handle).  
I've included the Blender file I used to create this. You might want to shorten it, the scoop is fairly tall.  
I wouldn't go leaving it to sit in a hot car if it's made from PLA. I wouldn't go trying to break up hard dirt or anything either. I'm not sure how well it will do with water either, I expect the porosity will largely depend on your printer and settings.  
Have fun!

comments.text: My 3 year old son desperately wanted a "green" shovel.  After printing this model for him, it has spread through my entire neighbourhood.  I have had to print 9 for different children.  Great job on the design it holds up well to real uses, and please know that it has made a positive impact on an entire group of children.

title: CR-10 Indicator Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Orient the object on it's back ( area with 3 slits on bed) with everything going up.

Didn't see a indicator mount for the X axis bar since some of us don't use the stock setup. Should fit snug on the printer, the hole for indicator is 9.8mm but can expand to accept slightly larger ones, smaller shafts will not work. Printed in PETG but you can use whatever. Supports on the overhang are optional.

If you are getting splitting or breakage when putting it on then increase infill to 40% or more. You also need to mount it overhang side first so angled it to seat then push hole side down till locked.

VERSION 2: Just modified the original to have more chamfers but overall the same

VERSION 3: I shortened the clip part to 13mm vs 15mm so it locks much tighter to the bar. This does require a new angle and more force to snap on. Not sure if PLA would be strong enough.

description.text: I made this to close the gap in the R2x enclosure hood where the feed tubes and wiring pass through. It has tabs that slide into a gap in the rear enclosure panel -- no fasteners required! I'm using it with fume filter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:125264 and corner hole-fillers http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:151513 by RodLaird. The ABS smell is almost entirely gone, and the build chamber stays a bit warmer (45-50C). I have attached a version with a flexible bellows section, and a flat version. I use the bellows version to give the feed tubes more play, but it may be difficult to print at lower resolutions.

This is a fairly large single piece -- adhesion may be an issue on warped build plates. I printed mine at 0.2mm and 30% linear infill on Kapton cleaned with isopropyl alcohol at 115C HBP temp, and experienced very minor edge-lift. (Some warping is ok.) You may be able to do better.  
I have scaled up the STL to 100.5% size to compensate for ABS thermal shrink. This gives me an excellent fit.   
The bellows will probably not print well at resolutions rougher than 0.2mm, or if you scale down the piece, since the walls are 0.4mm thick.

title: Y axis pulley bushes for TronXY P802MA

description.text:
I made some parts for silencing my printer the TronXY P802MA. After silencing the motors with silicone acoustic washers and PLA bushes to press the washers properly, I've been trying to silence the remaining noise. This was mainly coming from the Y axis pulley.

While inspecting the bearing it appears the wrong washers have been used. There are four washers in the assembly. The big ones are not the problem. The two small ones are supposed to grip the inner bearing ring, while the rest of the bearing rotates.

The issue is the small washers have an outside diameter of 10mm and the inner bearing has a larger diameter of 7mm. So the bearing is not working as a bearing, the outer bearing will be rubbing against the small washers and making a lot of noise!

This part replaces the small washer with the correct dimensions. It includes a sleeve for the play between the 5mm screw thread width and its 5.6mm inside diameter.

You will need two but it is best to print one and then let the bed cool and then remove it. Then print the second one. Your slicer might show some small gaps in the walls, a few don't matter.

If you don't let the bed cool properly the part will deform. You can re-form it by placing it on a heated bed.

Enjoy the silence!!

TronXY P802MA

Staining Wood PLA

After printing in Hatchbox wood PLA, I used a "stain marker" to stain the planter (my particular stain marker is a dark walnut stain made by Rust-Oleum). Apply the stain marker in slow, uniform strokes (all strokes in the same direction and that direction should follow the layer lines). By slightly overlapping the strokes, it simulates wood grain and gives the wood a more realistic look. I do NOT sand the wood before staining, because in this particular application I think the layer lines enhance the wood look.

Note, the stain marker I used is 2-in-1 stain + finish (and it's instant dry)... so it doesn't rub off and can get wet. If you use a different kind of stain, you may want to finish it with a protective coat so the stain doesn't rub onto your skin.

The Menger sponge is a 3D fractal which is more or less the 3D version of the Sierpinski carpet. In fact, each of the faces on the overall cube shape is a Sierpinski carpet.

STLs are provided for iterations from 0(plain cube) to 4.

A diagonally cut version of each is provided for ease of printing with FDM. Two diagonal prints will form the whole sponge.

There are many ways to create the shape of a Menger sponge in OpenSCAD, (and many already posted on thingivese), but the approach I used for this I think is a little different than others I've seen. As far as I know it is the fastest way to compute it in OpenSCAD(without using any external programs).

It starts by creating the 2d Sierpinski carpet. For this you draw a square, and cut a square out of the middle, and subdivide that shape into 8 smaller squares(3x3 with center missing) and cut square out of the center of those, etc.

Then we perform linear_extrude on the sierpinski carpet, along each axis: X,Y,Z

Finally by calculating the intersection of those three shapes, we get the Menger Sponge! Its that easy.

This approach is relatively efficient because most of the boolean / CSG operations are done in 2D which OpenSCAD can handle very quickly. The only 3D CSG operation is the final step, taking the intersection of just 3 objects.

Visualizing the intersection of 3 extruded Sierpinski carpets, one for each axis.

Token Tray for the tokens in the game Alchemists. Fits about 19 in the 4 long channels and 9 in the 4 smaller channels in the back.

It is made to close with magnets, I used 8mm diameter x 0.8 mm thickness, but the magnet spots are oversized to fit up to 10 mm diameter and 1 mm thickness.

To hold tighter I had to put 2x magnets in the back. In retrospect I should have probably just put 2 magnet spots on the back instead of the 1, but with the angles it was just easier to design with the 1.

I took into account the angle of the token cylinders so the lid should be able to freely come on and off vertically, but in practice the tolerances on the lid could have been abit larger so it can take a little wiggling to get it to close. Not a big deal, but a little annoying.

There are two top designs, the one in the pictures is the 'fancy' one. It is a little harder to print because of the overhangs it will cause. I printed it on the largest part of the top and did support for the other top angle. The steep angle there made it a little annoying to scrape away the supports. The simple lid will take a little more material but should print very easily upside down.

The tokens in the picture are 3d printed replacements for the slightly oversized cardboard chits that came with the game. You can find them here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2424571

comments.text:
Hi ! I saw many of your great model and I'm asking me : what kind of glue do you use for putting together those pieces ? (sorry for bad english :/ )
(and I also asking me if I do C3PO first or K2SO...)
comments.author: Roman_Policier

comments.text:
Hi
For larger pieces I use car body filler. Smaller parts I use two pack epoxy. I can't use superglue because I'm allergic to it.
Body filler can be thinned down with acetone to any consistency and it dries fast. Don't over apply it though or it will ooze out of the joint when you push it together.
C3PO is the easiest but K2SO is cool.

description.text:
The famous and well armed Fearless class heavy cruiser is replicated here. Known for their ability to take on numerous enemy ships outnumbered and, at times, in difficult tactical situations, the Fearless class set a new standard for ship design at the time. Some 13 were completed (although 12 more were ordered, they were converted to the similar but improved Gorgun Class), from 2599 to 2621, and they served in all areas of the Federation.
Their main tactic was to tilt to the enemy, target the enemy ship with its superior rangefinder and then train all guns for area fire. At shorter ranges the rear turrets could independently target the enemy and also co-link with other turrets, while the smaller turrets could also rely on the main range finder. At close range the cruiser could shoot in all directions if able to pivot freely on its axis.
The main armament remains 14 nuke slug guns, designed for long range fire to make the most of the superior rangefinder. It also carried 4 missile launchers which were considered secondary weapons to the officer corps who remained converts to the "gun club" tactics which became the primary tactical training at the time. However, after fighting independent pirate cruisers and after actions against Alien ships, they reconsidered the missiles as being as powerful and useful at the nuke slug gun armament. No beam weapons were used on the ships, although two laser turrets were tried on the FS Renown, which proved unsatisfactory and were soon replaced.

remixed_from.author: Meganudelauflauf
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Y-Axis Cable Chain Work&Force;&Weight; optimized

title: Anet A8 Print-in-place Y Cable Chain

description.text: After I printed my cable chain, It was really a pain to clean everything up and snap the links together. Tired fingers, hands, etc... After printing a few other things that were 'captive', such as the Gear Gearing (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451) and the Kobayashi Fidget Cube (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1790624) successfully, I figured I'd make this cable chain easier to assemble (actually, unnecessary to assemble, as it's already assembled, for the most part). Well, it worked out perfectly... Some links may have to be cut, but there's only a tiny little tab at the bottom of each joint that might have to be cut or snapped. Most of mine were easy to break free, while a few had to be cut. Enjoy!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Once printing is complete, the chain should snap loose at the bottom and become free to move. If it doesn't, use a sharp knife and, with the chain on its side, slide the knife into the slot between the adjacent links. At the bottom of each gap, there is a very tiny spot that connects the links together, and depending on material and printer tolerances, this might need to be cut. Most of mine snapped free, but a few had to be cut. This prints 16 links, but only 14 will fit, so you get a couple of extras... I may update the .stl with two 7-link chains later.

Use the brackets from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2366234 to mount. Best material would be ABS for the bed mount if you print with ABS, but mine is PLA, and seems to work okay. They're not really highly stressed, and don't seem affected much by the temperatures, at least the 95 C that I use for ABS. I do have the entire chain printed in ABS; just haven't installed it yet.

Basic Sketchup tasks, most of which I need to practice...

I just took the four-pack of links from the remixed thing, and copied one link in Sketchup, lined them up, and grouped them. Between those two, the only parts that were actually touching were the vertical parts, so I trimmed (pushed) 0.25mm from each side of one so they wouldn't print as one part. I then copied that one and deleted the original one, lined them up, and grouped them. Then copied the two, lined them up, and so on. Eventually, I got 16 links (14 plus two spares). That was too long for the bed, so I broke that into two groups of eight.

title: 96 Ball Nerf Multi-Cannon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The important thing is - do not aim in face - and ware safety glasses anyhow - it's hard to avoid 96 rebounding balls...

Back to fun:

Behold the 96 shot Nerf ball multi-cannon. There are 12 barrels and each hold 8 balls. Having got rather carried away with the air flow design, it's possible to load only 1 barrel and it'll work - but more fun to fire all 12.

Enjoy!

To make it you'll need the printed parts and the following:
---PET botttle - they can hold ~10bar, and the multi-cannon works well at 2, so that's great. Made it in the UK, so if made elsewhere, threads may differ.
---Schrader valves - search online for something like "4x Car TR43E Metal 11.5mm Clamp-in Tubeless Tyre Tire Wheel Schrader Valves"
---A full bore 1/4 turn 22mm valve. This works - http://www.screwfix.com/p/full-bore-lever-ball-valve-yellow-22mm/30584
---Quick setting epoxy to seal the valves, gauge and barrel to the plenum.
---A gauge - try searching for a 0-30psi or 0-2bar with a 1/8BSP thread

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is a herringbone (or double helical depending on your source) gear rack and pinion.

The design was made to connect to 12v gear motors to provide linear motion but could be used anywhere you need.

The specific intent was to have a 4 inch path of travel per rotation of the motor/gearbox output shaft, so this rack and pinion was not made to fit anything existing and should be considered custom.

Gear design properties:

  • 20 deg pressure angle
  • 45 deg helix angle
  • 0.75 inch width gear tread

Pinion properties:

  • 1 inch overall width (0.125 inch on either side of gear tread)
  • 0.3125 center bore
  • Actobotics hole layout (6-32 bolt and 0.770" spacing) for mounting to clamping hub; if another hole layout is needed, comment and I can create/upload
  • 4 inch circumference to ensure 1 rotation travels 4 inches linearly

Rack properties

  • Length varies; designed such that any size can fit together, one after another
  • 0.181 inch diameter mounting holes with 0.335 inch diameter head clearance

Rack Lengths:

  • 12 inch
  • 9.777 inch
  • 8 inch
  • 5.777 inch
  • 4 inch
  • 2.222 inch

Comments on ways to improve this design are welcome.

If any other length rack or pinion hole layout is needed, let me know and I will upload.

This is a work in progress.

# Changelog

## [0.4.0] - 2017-07-10
### Added
- Additional length racks
### Changed
- All racks now at lengths that allow them to be connected, one after another
- Pinion mounting holes made larger, again, now 0.160 inch diameter

## [0.3.0] - 2017-07-09
### Changed
- Pinion mounting holes made larger, again, now 0.154 inch diameter

## [0.2.0] - 2017-07-08
### Added
- 6 inch rack

### Changed
- Hole sizes increased due to tight fit

description.text:
3D prints sometimes show small strands of plastic on places where the printer shouldn’t print and the print head must only travel from one place to another. These unwanted strands of plastic is called stringing.

This is a quick and simple test model to show if your 3d printer tends to stringing. Use it to adjust your slicer's rectration settings.

print_settings.Notes:: If you plan to print the ThreadMe ver. see Post Print notes below RE: creating your own threading. Shell thickness should be factored into this. I usually use 3 or 4.

title: Session5, 3cmx3cm stack mount with integrated RX holder.

description.text:
A quick 45Deg design put together for a show piece which ended up with some unique features.

Pros
Fits on top of a 3cmx3cm stack.
Designed to hold a FrSky X4r in it's base
18g (excl. bolt/nut)
Can face either way, although the small menu button is tricky to access if you mount it backwards.
2 piece design allows for glass smooth surfaces on both sides.
Areas needing removable print supports are well hidden.
You can use a strap or zip ties to secure it to your frame.

Cons:
You need to deal with a bolt/nut to get the cam in and out.
If you use bolts they will need to come from the bottom with nut on top.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If you plan to print the ThreadMe ver. see Post Print notes below RE: creating your own threading. Shell thickness should be factored into this. I usually use 3 or 4.

Remove supports in nut cavities

and add a 4cm bolt with a nut on the other side.

I like to tap the 3m bolt into the plastic, hence the bolt holes on the ThreadMe file are a tight fit.

An electric screw driver is a must as if you can drive the screw all the way through in one go the bolt heats up and melts the plastic slightly. Drive all the way through in one action then let it cool. The plastic around the bolt hole melds to create a threaded jacket that perfectly fits the threaded bolt. The first time you unscrew after cooling will be tight but the action wears itself in nicely after that.

description.text:
It's a bowl. Originally envisaged as a coin bowl, I managed to prototype this out (read: muck up the dimensions enough) so that it's more like a giant ramen bowl or even, a candy bowl!

To deal with the problem of giving this guy some mass and proper heft, it's a two-part object with the bowl section, and a hidden base which can be ballasted with whatever you have handy - in my case, old platters from a dead HDD.

For printing, either choose the seamed or non-seamed pair. If you go for the seamed pair, then you may want the plugs as well if you don't have any doweling handy to assemble.

You will also probably need to sand the weight base to get a proper fit.. or just live with the infill, pour in lead shot and hot glue it down. That'd also work.

To note as well, the form is a giant, hollow, resonating cavity. It's loud. That's something I overlooked when designing it.. oops.

(If anyone's really interested enough, i'll dump the fusion files somewhere for general usage)

Printer:

Cocoon Create Plus (wanhao duplicator i3 plus, or whatever it's rebranded to in your country

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.14

Infill:

15%

Notes:
  • Generic Grey PLA from the lowest price bidder I could find.
  • Took about 24h all up (!!)
  • Did a double-thickness on the walls, so 0.8mm as I expected this piece to need some sanding/finishing and i wanted it to be fairly tough (was planning to throw coins in it..)

Gross design - the profile

It's a bowl, so for simplicity it's done up as a single profile that's fully revolved. What I've set up as control points are:

  • base radius
  • base-to-top-height
  • base thickness (important for the weight base!)
  • cap diameter
  • slope angle for the flare out
  • internal profile size/angle/thingie (which is just a giant circle profile)

A lot of them will affect each other, so the route to tweaking is to lock/unlock dimensions as desired and grab the remaining control handles to adjust the overall form.Since i'm in fusion, i'm just making heavy use of the constraints to keep certain things stable.

Note: I did NOT apply the fillet on the base in this step. May have made more sense, but I had it in my head to apply the fillet as a finishing step - ergo, not part of the profile.

Adding a weighted base - option A

There's a couple of options here, the simplest would be to add in a plane on the XY to split into two bits and then you can apply a boolean/cutout into the base to give you some hollow build volume where you can sink some lead/steel/ballast, and do the same with some holes in the top and bottom forms so you can use some dowel (or 3D printer pegs) to get your friction fit.

It's the most straightforward option, and the one that assembles/dissasembles the easiest.. but means you will have a seam to hide.

It's also the easiest option, so clearly, we're going to try something else..

Adding a weighted base - option B

As the base is the area I least care about showing (it is after all, hidden) I've instead gone for a seam where it won't be see, by using a circular cutout tool to separate the bowl into two pieces. The main object is my master, and the weight base is sacrificial - that's the piece that will get sanded to fit, etc etc. The extra feature/complication here are the finger holes to allow for removal.
